raw_text:
Bush to outline 'toughest' budget
 
 President Bush is to send his toughest budget proposals to date to the US Congress, seeking large cuts in domestic spending to lower the deficit.
 
 About 150 federal programs could be cut or axed altogether as part of a $2.5 trillion (£1.3 trillion) package aimed at curbing the giant US budget deficit. Defence spending will rise, however, while the proposals exclude the cost of continuing military operations in Iraq. Vice-President Dick Cheney said the budget was the "tightest" so far.
 
 At the heart of the administration's fifth budget, presented to Congress on Monday, is an austere package of domestic measures. These would see discretionary spending rise below the projected level of inflation.
 
 Such belt-tightening is designed to tackle the massive budget deficit increases of President Bush's first term. Mr Cheney admitted that the budget was the toughest of the Bush Presidency but argued it was "fair and responsible". "It is not something we have done with a meat axe, nor are we suddenly turning our back on the most needy people in our society," he said. The wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, increased expenditure on national security after 9/11 and the 2001 recession wiped out the budget surplus inherited by President Bush in 2001 and turned it into a record deficit. The shortfall is projected to rise to $427bn in 2005.
 
 Education, environmental protection and transport initiatives are set to be scaled back as a first step towards reducing the deficit to $230bn by 2009.
 
 Most controversially, the government is seeking to cut the Medicaid budget, which provides health care to the nation's poorest, by $45bn and to reduce farm subsidies by $587m. Spending on defence and homeland security is set to increase, although not by as much as originally planned. President Bush's proposals would see the Pentagon's budget rise by $19bn to $419.3bn while homeland security would get an extra $2bn.
 
 The budget does not include the cost of running military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, for which the administration in expected to seek an extra $80bn from Congress later this year.
 
 Also not featuring in the proposals is the cost of funding the administration's radical proposed overhaul of social security provision. Some expects believe this could require borrowing of up to $4.5bn trillion over a twenty year period. Despite the Republicans holding a majority in both houses of Congress, the proposals will be fiercely contested over the next few months.
 
 John McCain, a Republican Senator, said he was pleased the administration was prepared to tackle the deficit. "With the deficits that we are now running, I am glad the president is coming over with a very austere budget," he said. However, Democratic Senator Kent Conrad said the proposals exposed the country to huge financial commitments beyond 2009. "The cost of everything he [President Bush] advocates explodes," he said.
llama3.2:1b: Bush to send toughest budget proposal to Congress seeking large cuts in domestic spending to lower US deficit of $2.5 trillion (£1.3 trillion). About 150 federal programs could be cut or axed, including defence spending rising while military operations in Iraq excluded. Proposed package aims to curb deficit growth with discretionary spending below projected level of inflation.
llama3.2:3b: President Bush to send toughest budget proposal yet, aiming for $2.5 trillion in cuts, including 150 federal programs and Medicaid reduction of $45bn; defence spending to rise but excluding Iraq costs; proposed social security overhaul not included.
gemma2:2b: President Bush is proposing the "toughest" budget yet, aiming for $2.5 trillion in spending cuts to reduce the deficit. This includes scaling back discretionary programs, raising defense spending, and addressing Medicaid and farm subsidies.  The budget excludes costs of Iraq and Afghanistan operations, and social security reform, which faces opposition. The proposals are expected to be fiercely contested by Democrats and Republicans alike.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
President Bush will propose a budget that aims for significant cuts to domestic spending and national security programs as part of an austerity package aimed at reducing the US budget deficit. The proposals include:

- Discretionary spending rising below projected inflation, designed to cut the deficit by $427 billion.
- Cut spending on education, environmental protection, transportation initiatives, Medicaid, homeland security, and farm subsidies.
- Request additional funding for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.

Some controversial cuts include a proposed reduction of $45 billion in Medicaid spending and an increase of $80 billion in farm subsidies. The budget will not include the cost of running military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan or the radical overhaul of social security provision.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Bush to send toughest budget proposal yet seeking $230 billion cut in deficit by 2009, including scaling back Medicaid and farm subsidies while raising defense spending despite cuts in other areas.
qwen2.5:3b: President Bush will present his toughest budget yet to US Congress, aiming for large cuts in domestic spending and a $2.5 trillion package to reduce the deficit. This includes cutting 150 federal programs, rising defense spending, but excluding costs of Iraq operations. The budget aims to cut discretionary spending below inflation level by reducing education, environmental protection, and transport initiatives. Medicaid funding will decrease by $45bn and farm subsidies by $587m. Defence and homeland security spending will rise slightly. The proposals do not include the cost of running military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan nor a proposed overhaul of social security provision. While Republicans are generally supportive, Democrats oppose the budget as unsustainable beyond 2009.
opencoder:1.5b: Bush's toughest budget proposal to date is focusing on cuts in domestic spending to lower the deficit while raising defence spending. The administration's fiveth budget has been set up with a focus on curbing the major US budget deficits seen after President Bush's first term. It calls for a more balanced allocation of funds, including but not limited to education, environmental protection, and transport initiatives.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this entire text about President Bush's budget proposal into a concise summary. Let me read through it again to make sure I understand all the key points.

First, Bush is sending tough budget proposals to Congress. They're aiming for large cuts in spending to reduce the budget deficit. About 150 programs could be cut or axed out of a $2.5 trillion package. This includes increasing defense spending and not cutting costs related to keeping troops in Iraq. Vice President Cheney said it's the tightest budget so far.

The fifth budget is supposed to bring the deficit down to $230 billion by 2009, but it's still a huge gap from Bush's first term. The government plans to cut Medicaid by $45 billion and farm subsidies by $587 million. Defense and homeland security could go up by some amounts, though not as high as planned. They won't be cutting military costs in Iraq or Afghanistan, but they might have to get extra money from Congress for that.

Some people think this is a good move because it focuses on the most vulnerable groups, but there are big financial commitments involved. John McCain, a Republican, thinks it's a good idea and mentions borrowing up to $4.5 trillion over twenty years. However, some Democrats worry about these huge expenses beyond 2009.

Putting this all together, the summary should capture the main ideas: budget cuts aimed at reducing deficit, various programs cut or axed, focus on vulnerable populations, but also mention the large financial costs. I need to make sure I include all the critical points without getting too detailed.
</think>

President Bush is proposing a $2.5 trillion domestic budget to reduce the U.S. deficit, aiming for cuts in 150 federal programs. The budget includes increasing defense spending and excluding military costs from Iraq/ Afghanistan. Key cuts include Medicaid by $45 billion and farm subsidies by $587 million. Focus on vulnerable populations but with significant financial commitments beyond 2009. Cheney called it tight, while some Democrats warn of large expenses. McCain supports the plan, fearing future debt.
tinyllama:1.1b: Bush's budget for the US Congress seeks large cuts in domestic spendings, aiming at lowering the deficit. Key details are provided, including domestic measures, the planned increase in military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, a $427bn shortfall expected by 2005, and proposed budget cuts to Medicare, farm subsidies, and home security. Although not included in the proposal, the administration's radical social security overhaul is likely to require borrowing of up to $4.5bn over a 20-year period. Democratic Senator Kent Conrad criticized the proposed budget, stating that it exposed the country to massive financial commitments beyond 2009, while Republican Senator John McCain also agreed that the proposals were austere but necessary given the immense deficits.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
President Bush has proposed his toughest budget yet, seeking significant cuts in domestic spending to help lower the US government's deficit. Included in the proposal is a $2.5 trillion package aimed at reducing military expenditure and curbing the burden of ongoing operations in Iraq.

As part of this tough budget, President Bush wants to increase defense spending by $45 billion, an amount equivalent to the entire US military budget for one year. This move is in response to the substantial growth in the US deficit during his first term. Defense spending has increased more than 20% since 2001, with President Bush taking aim at two major areas: military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.

In addition to this, President Bush also wants to cut over $587 million from the Medicaid budget, which provides health care to the nation's poorest, and reduce farm subsidies by $587 million. This will see a reduction in funding for essential services such as education and environmental protection.

The administration is also expected to seek an additional $80 billion from Congress over a 24-month period to pay for these cuts. President Bush has not included the cost of funding his proposal's radical overhaul of social security provision, which some expect will require borrowing of up to $4.5 trillion over the next twenty years.

The budget also includes provisions for the US to enter into a new military alliance with NATO and an agreement on global warming with Russia. However, Democratic Senator Kent Conrad has criticised President Bush's proposal as too costly, arguing that it would leave the US vulnerable to financial commitments beyond 2009.
phi:2.7b: President Bush is proposing large cuts in domestic spending and programs that could be cut or axed altogether as part of a $2.5 trillion budget aimed at lowering the US deficit, but the proposals exclude the cost of continuing military operations in Iraq. The administration's fifth budget includes an austere package of domestic measures designed to tackle the massive budget deficit increases of President Bush' first term, including cuts to education, environmental protection and transport initiatives. Most controversially, the government is seeking to cut the Medicaid budget and reduce farm subsidies by $587m. The budget also includes increased spending on defence and homeland security. However, it does not include the cost of running military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. The proposed overhaul of social security provision will require borrowing of up to
orca-mini:3b: President George W. Bush is proposing a $2.5 trillion (£1.3 trillion) budget, including significant cuts in domestic spending and defense spending increases, to tackle the massive budget deficit inherited by his presidency. The proposals include reducing Medicaid spending by $45 billion and cutting farm subsidies by $587 million. While defense spending will rise, it does not include the cost of continuing military operations in Iraq. The budget also excludes the cost of funding social security reform, which could require borrowing of up to $4.5 billion over a twenty-year period. However, Vice President Dick Cheney argues that the budget is the "toughest" so far, and that it is fair and responsible. The budget is expected to face fierce opposition in Congress.
hermes3:3b:
President Bush proposes toughest US budget with domestic spending cuts to reduce deficit. 
 $2.5tr package includes cutting about 150 federal programs, increasing defence spending while excluding Iraq war costs.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: President Bush will propose the "toughest" budget to date to the US Congress, targeting large cuts in domestic spending to reduce the deficit. Around 150 federal programs may be cut or eliminated, with defense spending increasing. The budget aims to lower the $2.5 trillion package curbing the massive budget deficit increases of President Bush's first term, projected to rise to $427bn in 2005. Education, environmental protection, and transportation initiatives will initially face reductions. Controversially, the government plans to cut the Medicaid budget by $45bn and reduce farm subsidies by $587m. The budget does not include costs associated with military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan or social security overhaul funding. Fierce debates are expected over the proposals' content in Congress.
chatgpt-4o-latest: President Bush is presenting his toughest budget to Congress, proposing $2.5 trillion in spending with significant cuts to domestic programs to reduce the deficit. About 150 federal programs could be cut, while defense and homeland security spending will increase. The budget does not include costs for ongoing military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, for which an additional $80 billion will be requested. Key cuts include $45 billion from Medicaid and $587 million from farm subsidies. The deficit, which rose due to wars, post-9/11 security spending, and the 2001 recession, is projected to reach $427 billion in 2005 but is targeted to drop to $230 billion by 2009. The budget also excludes costs for a proposed Social Security overhaul, which could require borrowing up to $4.5 trillion over 20 years. While some Republicans support the austerity measures, Democrats argue the proposals create long-term financial burdens.
stablelm2:1.6b: President Bush submits his toughest budget to Congress, aiming for $2.5 trillion cuts in domestic spending to lower the budget deficit. About 10 federal programs may be eliminated, while defense spending will increase. The budget aims to reduce the budget deficit from President Bush's first term. Education, environmental protection, and transport initiatives will be scaled back, with a focus on reducing the deficit to $200 billion by 209. Controversially, the government seeks to cut the Medicaid budget by $1 trillion and farm subsidies by $500 billion. Spending on defense and homeland security is set to increase, but not as much as originally planned. The proposals will be fiercely contested over the next few months, particularly regarding social security funding which could require borrowing of up to $4.5 billion over a twenty-year period.
granite3.1-dense:2b: President Bush has unveiled a stringent, $2.5 trillion budget proposal to Congress, prioritizing large cuts in domestic spending to decrease the burgeoning US budget deficit. The plan targets approximately 150 federal programs for reduction or elimination. Defense expenditure will rise, excluding costs related to Iraq and Afghanistan operations. Key domestic areas affected include education, environmental protection, transportation, Medicaid, and farm subsidies. The administration aims to reduce the deficit from a projected $427 billion in 2005 to $230 billion by 2009. Despite being the most austere budget of Bush's presidency, Vice-President Cheney characterized it as "fair and responsible." Critics, like Democratic Senator Kent Conrad, warn that these proposals may lead to substantial financial obligations beyond 2009. Republican Senator John McCain expressed approval of the administration's deficit-reducing efforts but raised concerns about long-term financial commitments. The budget does not include costs for ongoing military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, which are expected to be addressed separately by the administration later this year.
